Journal.Title: The Science of the total environment

Article.ArticleTitle: Effect of silicon on barley growth and N<sub>2</sub>O emission under flooding.

AbstractText: The global climate change is related with greenhouse gas emission from cultivated soils - carbon dioxide, methane and nitrous oxide. The emissions of N<sub>2</sub>O also have negative influence on ozone layer of our planet. The major source of the nitrous oxide is denitrification process in soil, which controlled by specific soil microbe society. The pot experiment with flooding to accelerate the denitrification process and the application of the monosilicic acid as a source of soluble form of Si was carried out with barley. Several forms of nitrous oxide emission (unlimited carbon denitrification and potential denitrification with or without ethylene application) were measured. The obtained data showed that the application of monosilicic acid to brown soil when growing barley under conditions of soil flooding has a significant effect on nitrogen emission and can change the N<sub>2</sub>O:N<sub>2</sub> ratio. The application of the monosilicic acid reduced the uC-D N<sub>2</sub>O emission, while increased the PD N emission. Generally the application of the water soluble Si decreased the N<sub>2</sub>O:N<sub>2</sub> ratio. We suggested that the presence of monosilicic acid in the system provides a more complete denitrification process with the formation of N<sub>2</sub> in the NO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup> → NO<sub>2</sub><sup>-</sup> → NO→N<sub>2</sub>O → N<sub>2</sub> reaction sequence, while the deficiency of bioactive Si mainly provides the formation and emission of N<sub>2</sub>O. Considering that N<sub>2</sub> is not a greenhouse gas, we can conclude that application of monosilicic acid to the soil can reduce greenhouse gas emissions and reduce the impact of global climate change on agricultural activity.
